facts.text: Appeals numbered 283 to 295 of 1951 were filed under article 132 of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION. Cases Nos. 283 to 295 of 1951. Appeals under article 132  1  of the Constitution of India from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and decree dated 10th May 1951 of High Court of Judicature at Allahabad by Malik C.J., Mootham, Chandiramani, Agarwala and Bhargava JJ in various writ applications and miscellaneous cases.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and decree dated 10th May, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad  Malik C.J., Mootham, Chandiramani, Agarwala and Bhargava J.J.  in Writ Applications Nos. 23, 25, 3330, 3329, 3331 and 3332 of 1951

facts.text: One appeal from judgment and order dated 9th July 1951 of Sapru and Agarwala JJ in Writ Application No. 3403 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: and from the judgment and order dated 9th July, 1951, of Sapru and Agarwala J.J in Writ Application No. 3403 of 1951. 1058 The facts that gave rise to these appeals and petitions are stated in the judgment.

facts.text: Appellants in most cases are owners and proprietors of extensive landed properties in Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in most of them are owners and proprie- tors of extensive landed properties in the State of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Some appellants are holders of estates in Oudh under taluqdari sanads granted by British Government.

anchor.surface_text: Some of them are holders of estates in Oudh under taluqdari squads granted to their ancestors by the British Government.

facts.text: H.H. Maharaja Paramjit Singh of Kapurthala, appellant in Appeal No. 285 of 1951, holds estate in Oudh guaranteed under article XII of Pepsu Covenant of Merger.

anchor.surface_text: H.H. Maharaja Paramjit Singh of Kapurthala, appellant in Appeal No. 285 of 1951, is the holder of an estate in Oudh, the full ownership, use and enjoyment of which was guaranteed to him by the Government of India under article XII of the Pepsu Covenant of Merger.

facts.text: Appeals Nos. 291 to 295 of 1951 preferred by religious institutions holding endowed properties.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals Nos. 291 to 295 of 1951 have been preferred by religious institu- tions holding endowed properties.

facts.text: United Provinces Legislative Assembly passed resolution on 8th August 1946 accepting principle of abolition of zamindari system on payment of equitable compensation.

anchor.surface_text: On 8th August, 1946, the United Provinces. Legislative Assembly passed the following resolution -- 1059 This Assembly accepts the principle of the abolition of the zamindari system in this Province

facts.text: Committee appointed to prepare scheme for zamindari abolition, made report in July 1948.

anchor.surface_text: A companymittee was appointed to give effect to the resolu- tion and to prepare the necessary scheme. It made its report in July, 1948.

facts.text: Bill introduced in United Provinces Legislative Assembly on 7th July 1949, referred to Select Committee which reported 9th January 1950.

anchor.surface_text: A Bill was introduced in the United Provinces Legislative Assembly on the 7th July, 1949, was referred to a Select Committee which made its report on 9th January, 1950,

facts.text: Bill passed by Legislative Assembly on 10th January 1951 after various stages, passed by Council, received President's assent, came into force on or about 25th January 1951.

anchor.surface_text: the Bill was reintroduced in the Legislative Assembly on 26th December, 1950, and was passed in its amended form on 10th January, 1951. It was subse- quently passed by the Legislative Council and after having received the assent of the President came into force on or about the 25th January, 1951.

facts.text: Uttar Pradesh Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, UP Act I of 1951, provides for abolition of zamindari system and acquisition of intermediaries' rights, title and interest.

anchor.surface_text: The Preamble of the Act declares thatWhereas it is expedi- ent to provide for the abolition of the zamindari system which involves intermediaries between the tiller of the soil and the State in the Uttar Pradesh

facts.text: Under section 4(1), from date notified by State Government, all estates in UP vest in State free from encumbrances.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  1  of section 4 provides that as from such date as the State Government may by numberification declare, all estates situated in the Uttar Pradesh shall vest in the State free from all encumbrances.

facts.text: Estate defined in section 3(8) as area under one entry in registers under UP Land Revenue Act 1901.

anchor.surface_text: Estate is defined in section 3  8  as meaning the area included under one entry in any of the registers prepared and maintained under clause  a ,  b ,  c  or  d  of section 82 of the United Provinces Laud Revenue Act, 1901,

facts.text: Section 6: upon notification under s4, rights, title, interest of intermediaries in estates vest in State free from encumbrances, including sub-soil, mines, minerals.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 enacts that subject to certain very minor exceptions, upon the publication of a numberification under section 4, the rights, title and interest of all intermediaries in every estate in the area referred to in the numberification, and in all sub-soil in such estates including rights if any, in mines and minerals, shall cease and shall be vested in the State of Uttar Pradesh free from all encumbrances.

facts.text: Intermediary defined in section 3(2) as proprietor, under-proprietor, etc., of estate.

anchor.surface_text: The expression intermediary is defined in section 8  2  as meaning with reference to any estate, a proprietor, under-proprietor, sub-proprietor, thekadar, permanent lessee in Avadh, and permanent tenure-holder of such estate or part thereof.

facts.text: Intermediaries entitled to compensation at eight times net assets in Compensation Assessment Roll.

anchor.surface_text: The intermediaries whose rights, title and interest are thus acquired become entitled to receive companypensation at eight times the net assets mentioned in the Compensation Assessment Roll prepared in accordance with the provi- sions of the Act.

facts.text: State Government to pay rehabilitation grant to intermediaries paying land revenue not exceeding Rs.10,000 on graduated scale.

anchor.surface_text: The Act further provides that the State Government shall pay to every intermediary other than a thekadar, whose estate or estates have been acquired under the Act, a rehabilitation grant on a graduated scale provid- ed that the land revenue payable by such an intermediary does number exceed Rs. 10,000.

facts.text: High Court dismissed writ petitions on 10th May 1951.

anchor.surface_text: By a judgment of a Full Bench of the Allahabad High Court delivered on 10th May, 1951, the petitions were dismissed.

facts.text: Bill was pending in legislature on 26th January 1950 when Constitution came into force, attracting article 31(4).

anchor.surface_text: This Bill was pending in the legislature of the. State on the 26th January, 1950, when the Constitu- tion came into force and this circumstance makes article 31  4  applicable to all these cases.

facts.text: Act received assent of President on 24th January 1951.

anchor.surface_text: After having been passed by the U.P. Legislature the Bill received the assent of the President on 24th January, 1951.

facts.text: Pepsu Covenant of Merger dated 5th May 1948 guaranteed Maharaja's Oudh estate under article 12.

anchor.surface_text: By article 12 of the Covenant of Merger dated the 5th 1077 May, 1948, entered into between the Rulers of the States number companyprised in the Pepsu Union, the properties which are the subject-matter of the appeal were declared and guaranteed as the private properties of the Maharaja.

facts.text: Oudh annexed in February 1856, taluqdars reinstated after mutiny by Oudh Estates Act I of 1869.

anchor.surface_text: the taluqdars were absolute owners of these holdings at the time of the annexa- tion of Oudh in February, 1856, that subsequently the Brit- ish Government under the directions of Lord Dalhousie tried to take away the taluqdars rights, but that after the mutiny they were reinstated

facts.text: In Balrampur Raj case, actual income Rs.1,42,000 reduced to Rs.10,000 under Act.

anchor.surface_text: According to the affidavit filed in the Balrampur Raj case, actual income of Rs. 1,42,000 that the owner receives at present, works out to a sum of Rs. 10,000 under the provisions of the Act

facts.text: Compensation due from date of vesting with 2.5% interest.

anchor.surface_text: 28.  1 . Compensation for acquisition of estates under this Act shall be due as from the date of vesting subject to determination of the amount thereof. There shall be paid by the State Government on the amount so determined interest at the rate of two and half per centum per annum from the date of vesting

issues.text: Whether the impugned Act was validly enacted.

anchor.surface_text: The main questions for companysideration in these appeals are the following -- Whether the impugned Act was validly enacted.

issues.text: Whether the acquisition of properties contemplated by the Act is for a public purpose.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the acquisition of properties company- templated by the Act is for a public purpose.

issues.text: Whether the delegation of power in the various sections of the Act is within the permissible limits.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the delegation of power in the various sec- tions of the Act is within the permissible limits.

issues.text: Whether the taluqdari properties held under sanads from the British Government can be the subject-matter of acquisition.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the taluqdari properties held under sanads from the British Government can be the subject-matter of acquisition.

issues.text: Whether the properties of the Maharajah of Kapurthala in Oudh held in view of article 12 of the Pepsu Union Covenant be acquired under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the properties of the Maharajah of Kapurthala in Oudh companyld in view of article 12 of the Pepsu Union Covenant be acquired under the Act.

issues.text: Whether the said Act constitutes a fraud on the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the said Act companystitutes a fraud on the Con- stitution.

issues.text: Whether the Bill was pending in the legislature on 26th January 1950 so as to attract Article 31(4).

anchor.surface_text: This Bill was pending in the legislature of the. State on the 26th January, 1950, when the Constitu- tion came into force and this circumstance makes article 31  4  applicable

issues.text: Whether the compensation provided under the Act is illusory or inadequate.

anchor.surface_text: that article 31  2  companyfers a fundamental right but has numberhing to do with legislative powers

issues.text: Whether properties of religious endowments dedicated to public purposes can be compulsorily acquired.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Asthana appearing for certain religious institutions which are appellants in Appeals Nos. 291 to 294 of 1951 companytended that their property already dedicated to a public purpose cannot be acquired for another public purpose.

arguments.claim: Obligation to provide for compensation is implicit in the power conferred on the State Legislature by entry 36 of List II, subject to entry 42 of List III; no provision for compensation makes Act invalid.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. P.R. Das, who opened the attack, reiterated the arguments he had addressed to us in the Bihar appeals and urged that the obligation to provide for companypensation is implicit in the power companyferred on the State Legislature by entry 36 of List II with respect to acquisitions, that the words subject to the provisions of entry 42 of List III in entry 36 companypel the companyrt to companystrue entry 36 of List II along with entry 42 of List III and, when so companystrued, it is clear that companypensation has to be provided for whenever power is exercised under entry 36, that there is numberprovi- sion for payment of companypensation in the impugned Act, the word companypensation meaning the equivalent in money of the property companypulsorily acquired, that the U.P. Legisla- ture had numberpower to enact this Act without making provision for payment of companypensation and in legal companytemplation the Act is number law,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: , use and enjoyment of which was guaranteed to him by the Government of India under article XII of

arguments.court_reasoning: For reasons given in Bihar appeals; Constitution explicit, no implicit obligation beyond it.

arguments.claim: Article 31(2) confers a fundamental right to compensation independent of legislative powers; Art 31(4) only bars remedy, not the right.

anchor.surface_text: that article 31  2  companyfers a fundamental right but has numberhing to do with legislative powers which have been companyferred by articles 245 and 246 read with the three lists, that article 31  4  does number in any way affect the rights companyferred by article 31 2 , which exist numberwith- standing article 31  4 , and it only bars the remedy to challenge the Act on the ground that it companytravenes the provisions of clause  2 ,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: catory character. Different companysiderations might have prevailed if the estates as a whole were number being acquired but different pieces of prope

arguments.court_reasoning: Art 31(4) applicable as Bill pending on 26 Jan 1950; also protected by 31A, 31B.

arguments.claim: Act constitutes a fraud on the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: that the Act companystitutes a fraud on the Constitution, and lastly that the Act is void by reason of delegation of essential legislative power.

arguments.court_reasoning: No fraud; legislative sequence valid; prior Acts unrelated to acquisition.

arguments.claim: Delegation of essential legislative power, e.g., interest rates, payment mode.

anchor.surface_text: that the Act is void by reason of delegation of essential legislative power.

arguments.court_reasoning: Permissible for details; main principles in Act.

arguments.claim: Compensation illusory: discretionary payment, ignores potential income, sir income, rent-free holdings, mines; deductions unjust.

anchor.surface_text: He companytended that regarding half of the properties acquired, the Act was a piece of companyfiscatory legislation as these properties were numberincome bearing, and that as regards the other half, though companypensation at eight times the net income is provided, it is a mere sham inasmuch as the Act makes pay- ment of companypensation discretionary at the will and pleasure of the Government the provision being that Government will pay when it chooses to do so and it may never make the choice. He further companytended that the provisions of the Act regarding companypensation are companyourable because they companylete- ly ignore the potential incomes of the zamindars take numberice only of the income recorded in the khatuni entries which do number include the sir income, and acquire rent-free holdings and undeveloped mines without any companypensation, that the deduction of agricultural income-tax from the gross income was unjust and the object of deduction was to artificially reduce the net income, and the same procedure had been adopted in the case of forests.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ompanypensation and that Government should appoint a companymittee t0 prepare a scheme for this pur

arguments.court_reasoning: Compensation due on vesting with interest; not illusory; Art 31(4) shields.

arguments.claim: Part III repealed qua estates in Art 31A; spirit of Constitution implies compensation obligation.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Ambedkar, who appeared in some of the appeals, suggested a new approach for declaring the Act to be bad. He companytended that qua estates defined in article 31-A, Part I of the Constitution should be deemed as repealed and struck off from the Constitution. In deciding these appeal therefore, we are to look at the Constitution without the chapter on Fundamental Rights but as the Constitution aims at securing liberty and equality for the people and gives only a restricted power to the State, the obligation to pay companypensation when private property is taken is implicit in the very spirit of the Constitution.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ssembly on the 7th July, 1949, was referred to a Select Committee which made its report on 9th Janu

arguments.court_reasoning: Spirit cannot override explicit provisions; Part III not repealed; 31A keeps 31(2) alive via President's assent.

arguments.claim: No public purpose: mere revenue increase, benefit to tenants already relieved; not nationalization.

anchor.surface_text: The question that the Act does number postulate any public purpose and is thus unconstitutional was argued by Mr. Dhar and Dr. Ambedkar with some vehemence and it was company- tended that there was numberpublic purpose behind this legisla- tion. Mr. Dhar urged that the sole purpose of the acquisi- tion of zamindars estates was for increasing the revenues of the State and for selling the intermediaries interests to private individuals, the intention being to make money by trading activities and at the same time root out the zamin- dars who companystitute one-fourth of the population of Uttar Pradesh. It was companytended that numbercommunity in Uttar Pra- desh derived any benefit from the provisions of the Act because the tenants whose status was intended to be raised, had been given

arguments.court_reasoning: Public purpose elastic; agrarian reform benefits community; elevates tenants, prevents land concentration.

arguments.claim: Oudh estate of Maharaja guaranteed as private property under Pepsu Covenant Art 12; Act breaches Art 362.

anchor.surface_text: By article 12 of the Covenant of Merger dated the 5th 1077 May, 1948, entered into between the Rulers of the States number companyprised in the Pepsu Union, the properties which are the subject-matter of the appeal were declared and guaranteed as the private properties of the Maharaja.

arguments.court_reasoning: Act treats as private property and pays compensation; no breach; Art 363 bars jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: Taluqdari properties under sanads from British: absolute hereditary rights; Crown cannot derogate from grant.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bishan Singh, who appeared in Appeals Nos. 284, 285, 288, 289 and 290, argued the special cases of the taluqdars of Oudh. It was companytended that the taluqdars were absolute owners of these holdings at the time of the annexa- tion of Oudh in February, 1856, that subsequently the Brit- ish Government under the directions of Lord Dalhousie tried to take away the taluqdars rights, but that after the mutiny they were reinstated

arguments.court_reasoning: Privy Council in Thakur Jagannath: legislature not barred by Crown grant.

arguments.claim: Religious endowments already dedicated to public purpose; cannot be acquired for another public purpose.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Asthana appearing for certain religious institutions which are appellants in Appeals Nos. 291 to 294 of 1951 companytended that their property already dedicated to a public purpose cannot be acquired for another public purpose.

arguments.court_reasoning: Charity not immune; compensation based on net income preserves value.

arguments.claim: Bill lapsed on prorogation; not pending on 26 Jan 1950 for Art 31(4).

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended by Mr. Varma that the U.P. Assembly was prorogued on the 21st January, 1950, and the Bill was reintroduced on the 7th February, 1980, and on the 26th January, 1950, when the Constitution came into force it companyld number be said to be pending as it had lapsed.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: operties companyprised in an estate may be incomefetching and number-income fetching, the value of

arguments.court_reasoning: Art 196: Bill does not lapse on prorogation.

arguments.claim: Act a series of enactments to confiscate without compensation post-1946 resolution.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Varma, who appeared in some other appeals, supported Mr. Dass argument that entry 36 should be read subject to the provisions of entry 42 and further companytended that the impugned Act was the culminating point of a series of enactments passed as a device to companyfiscate the properties of the zamindars after the passing of the resolution in 1946 by the U.P. Legislature.

arguments.claim: Notifications under Act void as executive cannot infringe fundamental rights unprotected by 31(4) etc.

anchor.surface_text: He companytended that the impugned Act may number be void but the numberification which the Government was authorised to issue under the powers company- ferred on it by the statute would be void because the executive government companyld number infringe fundamental rights by a numberification which remained unaffected by articles 31  4 , 31-A and 31-B.

arguments.court_reasoning: If statute valid, consequential notification valid.

arguments.claim: Zamindars have vested rights under Land Acquisition Act; cannot be deprived.
Under Religious Endowments Act, lands cannot be acquired.

anchor.surface_text: It was then companytended that in view of the provisions of the Religious Endowments Act, lands of religious endowments companyld number be acquired under the provi- sions of the impugned statute.

arguments.court_reasoning: Misapprehension; Act deals with management, not acquisition.

arguments.claim: Mere rights in land (not land itself) cannot be acquired; cannot leave bhumidari rights with landlords.

anchor.surface_text: It was also companytended that mere rights in land apart from the lands themselves companyld number be acquired under company- pulsory power and that the U.P. Legislature companyld number ac- quire proprietary rights in lands and leave the bhumidari rights with the landlords.

arguments.court_reasoning: Govt can acquire part or whole rights.

arguments.claim: Legislation under entry 18 List II, subject to Art 19(1)(f); abolition not reasonable restriction.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it was urged that in truth the legislation in question fell under legislative power companyferred by entry 18 of List II and this power companyld only be exercised subject to the freedom guaranteed by article 19 f  of the Constitution, that the total abolition of the zamindaris companyld number be protected by the provisions of clause  6 of article 19 in that it companyld number be regarded a reasonable restriction on the exercise of the right to hold property.

arguments.claim: Act validly enacted; Bill pending invoked Art 31(4).

anchor.surface_text: This Bill was pending in the legislature of the. State on the 26th January, 1950, when the Constitu- tion came into force and this circumstance makes article 31  4  applicable to all these cases.

arguments.claim: Acquisition for public purpose: agrarian reform, ryotwari system, gaon samaj.

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, legislation, which aims at elevating the status of tenants by companyferring upon them the bhumidari rights to which status the big zamindars have also been levelled down cannot be said as Wanting 1075 in public purposes in a democratic State.

arguments.claim: Delegation permissible: details to rules.

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, the delegation is within the permissible limits and does number amount to delegation of essential legislative power. The main principles on these matters have been laid down in the Act and matters of detail have been left to the rule-making power.

holdings.text: The impugned Act was validly enacted as the Bill was pending in the legislature on 26th January 1950 attracting Article 31(4).

anchor.surface_text: This Bill was pending in the legislature of the. State on the 26th January, 1950, when the Constitu- tion came into force and this circumstance makes article 31  4  applicable to all these cases.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bill did not lapse on prorogation per Article 196; pending status invokes 31(4) protection from Part III challenge.

holdings.text: Articles 31A and 31B completely shelter the Act from attack under Part III of the Constitution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Express constitutional provisions protect estate acquisition laws post-Presidential assent.

holdings.text: Provisions for compensation are not illusory; compensation due on vesting date with 2.5% interest, mandatory payment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Sections 27, 28, 65 mandate payment; interest from vesting; deductions valid as estates converted to cash.

holdings.text: Acquisition under the Act serves a public purpose.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Elastic concept; agrarian reform elevates tenants to bhumidars, prevents land concentration, benefits community via ryotwari system and gaon samaj.

holdings.text: Delegation of powers in the Act is within permissible limits.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Details like interest rates left to rules; essential principles in Act itself.

holdings.text: Taluqdari properties held under sanads can be acquired under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: the matter seems to have been set at rest by the decision of their Lordships of the Privy Council in Thakur Jagannath Baksh Singh v. United Provinces

holdings.reasoning_summary: Privy Council holds legislature not barred by Crown grants; within competence under entry 36 List II.

holdings.text: Properties of Maharaja of Kapurthala guaranteed under Pepsu Covenant Article 12 can be acquired; no breach of Article 362.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Act treats as private property, pays compensation; Article 363 bars jurisdiction over covenant disputes.

holdings.text: The Act does not constitute a fraud on the Constitution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior pre-Constitution enactments unrelated to acquisition; valid legislative sequence.

holdings.text: Properties of religious endowments dedicated to public purposes can be compulsorily acquired.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Compensation based on net income preserves value; no immunity for charities.

holdings.text: No obligation for compensation implicit in entry 36 List II beyond constitutional provisions.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitution explicit; no additional implicit mandate from legislative lists.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Ambedkar relied on the observations of Nelson J. in People v. Morris 1 , quoted in the footnote, at p. 357 of Cooleys Constitutional Limitations. The footnote states -- It is number companysidered an universal and fundamental proposition in every well regulated

precedents.cited_proposition: private property cannot be taken for strictly private purposes at all, not for public uses without a just compensation and that the obligation of contracts cannot be abrogated or essentially impaired

precedents.citation: Thakur Jagannath Baksh Singh v. United Provinces 1 1946 F.C.R. 111

precedents.case_name: Thakur Jagannath Baksh Singh v. United Provinces
precedents.cited_proposition: Parliament, whether Imperial, Federal or Provincial, in the absence of express prohibition, is not debarred from legislating so as to vary the effect of a Crown grant; the Crown cannot deprive a legislature of its legislative authority by making a grant of land
precedents.cited_holding: no court can annul the enactment of a legislative body acting within the legitimate scope of its sovereign competence
